briefOverview: Jacob proclaims the “infinite atonement” of the Holy One of Israel, teaching universal resurrection, final judgment, and the narrow way of covenant discipleship. He warns against pride and sin, urges repentance and baptism, and affirms God’s covenants to gather Israel.
summary: After recalling God’s covenants to restore and gather Israel, Jacob teaches that because of the Fall, an infinite atonement was necessary so that death and hell would deliver up their captives through the resurrection of the Holy One of Israel. All will rise, possess perfect knowledge, and stand before God to be judged, with the righteous inheriting joy and the unrepentant consigned to everlasting punishment. Christ suffers the pains of all and commands all to repent, be baptized, and endure to the end; mercy covers those without law, but those who sin against greater light are warned. Jacob denounces pride, reliance on learning or wealth over God, and various sins, calling his people to humility and spiritual-mindedness. He teaches that the gate is narrow and personally kept by the Holy One of Israel, who cannot be deceived, and invites all to “come to the waters” and feast on imperishable things. Jacob symbolically shakes his garments as a witness, urges preparation for judgment, and closes with a promise that their seed will be preserved as a righteous branch of Israel.
externalContext: Within the Book of Mormon narrative, Jacob (Nephi’s brother) addresses an early Nephite community that left Jerusalem around the time of the Babylonian crisis; his sermon follows a public reading of Isaiah (2 Nephi 6–8). Prophetic “woe” oracles and appeals to covenant restoration reflect standard Israelite prophetic motifs of the First Temple/early exilic period. The title “Holy One of Israel,” frequent in Isaiah, underscores continuity with Israel’s prophetic tradition. References to repentance and baptism in a pre-Christian setting align with Book of Mormon claims about pre-Christian ordinances; in ancient Judaism, ritual washings (mikva’ot) were practiced, though their relation to Christian baptism develops later.
externalReferences: Jacob’s invitation “come…buy wine and milk without money” clearly echoes Isaiah 55:1–2, which he adapts as a call to seek God’s imperishable gifts. His mention of the serpent’s deception of the first parents alludes to Genesis 3:1–6. The imagery of the narrow way and the exclusive “gate” parallels Matthew 7:13–14 and John 10:7–9. The scene of death and hell delivering up the dead resonates with Revelation 20:13–15, while the universal resurrection through Christ accords with 1 Corinthians 15:20–22.

sectionTitles.title: Repentance, Woes, and the Narrow Way

practicalQuestions: Where might learning, status, or wealth be dulling my willingness to heed God’s counsel?
What concrete steps will help me enter and stay on the narrow way (faith, repentance, baptism, endurance)?
How does believing in a universal resurrection and final judgment shape my daily choices now?
In what ways am I spending effort on what cannot satisfy instead of feasting on what endures?
Whom have I wronged, and how can I repent today rather than “waste the days of my probation”?
How can I regularly remember God’s covenants and promises to sustain hope and humility?
uncertainAreas: The precise scope of “those who have not the law” (vv. 25–26) and how mercy applies to varying degrees of knowledge; whether terms like “everlasting fire” and “lake of fire” are literal or primarily metaphorical; how to parse the statement that the gatekeeper “employeth no servant” (v. 41) alongside broader ideas of delegated ministry; and the extent of “he suffereth the pains of every living creature” (v. 21).
